text: Well, that is come back to the issue of overfitting. We have little success using machine learning to directly generate a trading signal out there. And that was also a point made by Lopek de Prado because oftentimes a trading strategy needs to have a sensible fundamental reason for it to work. If it is a pure black box model, even if the creator doesn't know why it works, many investors and investors, including the creator himself, will have some doubts on whether we should be competent in that model. Every model would have a drawdown. And in a drawdown, if you don't know why it has a drawdown, one is tempted to shut it down for both psychological as well as real theoretical reasons, namely overfitting. It is not recommended to actually apply machine learning to the basic signal generation. Now I know many people differ. Numerary, for example, is quant world. I'm sorry, world point. Like to take completely black box signals and put them together, and they no doubt have their own success. But from my personal experience, it hasn't worked that way for us. And it's not because of lack of trying. I've been trying to do that since 1997 and have never had much success using the black box approach in generating real problems.
